items.title: Black Friday sale of medical weight-loss treatment prompts concerns
items.description: International company Juniper is among the concerns of eating disorder industry bodies, having run a Black Friday sale and made a social media comment about "pesky Aussie laws" to promote its medications.

items.title: Trump pledges Ukraine security guarantee ahead of Zelenskyy meeting
items.description: Donald Trump is hosting Volodymyr Zelenskyy at Mar-a-lago to discuss the finer points of a 20-point plan put forward by Washington.

items.title: Overall winner yet to be decided as Sydney to Hobart race enters day four
items.description: The yacht race has entered the fourth day, after Master Lock Comanche claimed line honours late on Sunday.

items.title: Courtesy wave dying out, say truckies, but still alive on back roads
items.description: For generations, the courtesy wave has been etched into the Australian culture, but is it on the verge of dying?

items.title: Caravan customers furious ASIC ignored whistleblower before collapse
items.description: Anger is growing after revelations the corporate watchdog failed to investigate allegations against luxury caravan manufacturer Zone RV.

items.title: NGOs fear lifesaving aid program blockage in Gaza under new Israeli rules
items.description: The Israeli government has introduced new rules for aid organisations, including that they must not engage in any activities or criticism which "delegitimise" the state of Israel.

items.title: Iranian president says Tehran at war with US, Israel, and Europe

featured_image.name: Iran president says US, Israel, Europe waging ‘full-fledged war’ on country

items.description:
Iranian President Masoud Pezeshkian declared on December 27 that his country is in a "full-fledged war" with the United States, Israel, and Europe[1][2][3], marking a dangerous escalation as Tehran rapidly rebuilds its nuclear capabilities following devastating military strikes and abandons all international constraints on its atomic program.

The stark warning comes as Iran possesses 441 kilograms of uranium enriched to 60% purity as of June 2025, according to International Atomic Energy Agency reports[4][5][6]—alarmingly close to the 90% weapons-grade threshold needed for nuclear weapons. Western intelligence agencies warn that Iran has assembled all necessary components for weaponization and could complete the process quickly if ordered[7][8].

items.title: Harvard physicist disputes NASA on interstellar comet

featured_image.name: NASA releases close-up pictures of interstellar comet 3I/Atlas - PBS

items.description:
As the interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS recedes from its closest approach to Earth last week, a contentious scientific debate has intensified over whether the mysterious visitor from beyond our solar system could be artificial technology rather than a natural object. Harvard physicist Avi Loeb continues to argue that unusual features of the comet warrant consideration of extraterrestrial origins, while NASA and mainstream astronomers maintain overwhelming evidence points to natural cometary behavior.

On December 18, the Breakthrough Listen program conducted a technosignature search of 3I/ATLAS using the 100-meter Green Bank Telescope, less than 24 hours before the object's closest approach to Earth[1][2]. The search, which scanned radio frequencies from 1 to 12 gigahertz, found no artificial signals down to a sensitivity of 100 milliwatts[2]. "We report a nondetection of candidate signals down to the 100 mW level," researchers wrote in findings published this week[2].

The comet passed within approximately 168 million miles of Earth on December 19, posing no threat to our planet[3][4]. Discovered on July 1 by the NASA-funded ATLAS telescope in Chile, 3I/ATLAS is only the third confirmed interstellar object ever detected passing through our solar system, following 1I/'Oumuamua in 2017 and 2I/Borisov in 2019[3][5].

items.title: Zelenskyy to present updated 20-point peace plan in meeting with Trump

featured_image.name: As Trump and Zelenskyy meet in Florida, Kyiv hopes this time will be different

items.description:
Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskyy arrived in Florida on Sunday to meet with President Donald Trump at Mar-a-Lago, presenting a revised 20-point peace proposal aimed at ending nearly four years of war with Russia[1][2][3][4][5]. The meeting, scheduled for 1 p.m. local time, comes one day after Russia unleashed a massive attack on Kyiv using approximately 500 drones and 40 missiles, killing at least two people and leaving a third of the capital without heating[1][6][7][8][9].

Zelenskyy described the plan as "about 90% ready," signaling what both Ukrainian and U.S. officials characterized as substantial progress in negotiations[4][5][10][11]. The proposal includes NATO-style security guarantees modeled on Article 5, provisions for demilitarized zones in eastern Ukraine, and arrangements for disputed territories[12][13][14][15]. However, Trump emphasized his final authority over any agreement, telling Politico on Friday: "He doesn't have anything until I approve it. So we'll see what he's got"[16][4][5].

items.title: Thwaites Glacier retreating faster than expected, study warns

featured_image.name: Scientists weigh giant sea curtain to shield 'Doomsday Glacier' from ...

items.description:
Antarctica's Thwaites Glacier is retreating faster than anticipated, with new research revealing fractures and underwater erosion that threaten to destabilize the massive ice sheet and trigger catastrophic sea-level rise affecting hundreds of millions of coastal residents worldwide.

Scientists from the International Thwaites Glacier Collaboration released findings in their 2025 report showing the glacier's retreat "has accelerated considerably over the past 40 years"[1]. While a full collapse is unlikely to occur in the next few decades, the glacier "is set to retreat further, and faster, through the 21st and 22nd centuries," potentially leading to a general collapse of the West Antarctic Ice Sheet by the 23rd century[1][2].

items.title: Trump speaks with Putin ahead of Zelensky meeting

featured_image.name: Trump to meet with Zelenskyy at Mar-a-Lago as peace talks advance

items.description:
President Donald Trump announced on Sunday that he had a "good and very productive" phone call with Russian President Vladimir Putin ahead of his scheduled meeting with Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky at his Mar-a-Lago resort in Florida[1][2][3][4]. The meeting, set for Sunday afternoon, is part of ongoing efforts to advance a 20-point peace plan aimed at ending the nearly four-year conflict between Russia and Ukraine.

The White House confirmed that Trump and Zelensky would meet at 3 p.m. local time in Palm Beach[5][6]. Zelensky arrived in the United States after stopping in Halifax, where Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney pledged an additional $2.5 billion in economic assistance for Ukraine[7][8][9]. The aid package includes loan guarantees to the World Bank and financing that will enable the International Monetary Fund to lend an additional $8.4 billion to Ukraine[10].

items.title: 'Happy it's over': Kyrgios defeats Sabalenka in new battle of the sexes
items.description: Australia's Nick Kyrgios defeated women's world number one Aryna Sabalenka in the latest 'battle of the sexes'. The Aussie, who has fallen outside the ATP top 600 after barely playing for three years, won 6-3, 6-3.

items.title: Russia launches three Iranian satellites into orbit

featured_image.name: Russia's Soyuz-2.1b rocket with 52 satellites delivered to ... - YouTube

items.description:
Russia successfully placed three Iranian-made satellites into orbit Sunday, marking the latest milestone in deepening space cooperation between Moscow and Tehran as both nations face Western sanctions.

The Paya, Zafar-2, and Kowsar satellites launched from Russia's Vostochny Cosmodrome in the Far East aboard a Soyuz-2.1b rocket at 13:18 GMT, according to state media reports from both countries[1][2][3]. The satellites will orbit approximately 500 kilometers above Earth and are designed for agricultural monitoring, natural resource management, and environmental observation[4][1][5].

items.title: Families of Bondi victims call for federal royal commission
items.description: Loved ones of those killed and injured in the Bondi Beach attack say rising antisemitism requires a "powerful national response", piling pressure on Anthony Albanese for a royal commission.

items.title: China develops surface that turns radar into electricity

featured_image.name: How China's 6G smart surface could turn radar into a power source

items.description:
Chinese scientists at Xidian University have developed a multifunctional electromagnetic surface capable of converting radar waves into usable electricity, a breakthrough that could reshape both military stealth operations and next-generation wireless communications[1][2][3][4].

The technology, published in the December 2025 issue of National Science Review, employs reconfigurable intelligent surfaces (RIS) that can simultaneously harvest energy from ambient electromagnetic waves while supporting 6G telecommunications[4]. Instead of simply evading enemy radar, future stealth aircraft could absorb those same detection beams to power onboard systems or communications equipment, according to the research team led by Yajie Mu and colleagues[1][2][3].

items.title: Brigitte Bardot, the French star you 'had to see to believe'
items.description: Few epitomised French chic like Brigitte Bardot, the doe-eyed beauty whose sensuality rocked a post-war world.

items.title: Iconic French star Brigitte Bardot dies aged 91
items.description: The French actor and singer was a screen siren of the 1950s and 1960s who in later life became a prominent animal rights campaigner.

items.title: NASA under pressure to release data on anomalous comet

featured_image.name: New NASA, ESA images show 3I/ATLAS getting active ahead of its close encounter with Earth

items.description:
The interstellar comet 3I/ATLAS, which passed Earth last week at a distance of 167 million miles, continues to generate controversy as scientists and lawmakers press NASA for greater transparency about the third confirmed visitor from beyond our solar system[1][2]. The rare cosmic object has exhibited unpredictable trajectory changes and unusual features that challenge standard comet models, intensifying calls for the release of raw observational data[3][4].

In late December, astronomers observed that 3I/ATLAS had deviated from its predicted path due to non-gravitational acceleration—forces not accounted for by gravity alone[3][5]. According to Harvard astrophysicist Avi Loeb, the comet experienced a "radial acceleration away from the Sun of 1.1x10^{-6} au per day squared," which would require the object to have shed approximately 13 percent of its total mass during its October perihelion passage[5][6]. However, such a massive gas cloud has not been detected, leaving the acceleration mechanism unexplained[7].

items.title: Turkey serves as hub for Russian oil flowing to Europe

featured_image.name: Turkey cuts Russian Urals oil imports in November, diversifies with Kazakh, Iraqi supply

items.description:
Turkish ports have become a critical transit hub for Russian oil products reaching the European Union, even as Brussels moves to eliminate Russian energy imports by late 2027, multiple investigations and recent reports reveal.

Tankers routinely discharge thousands of barrels from Russia at storage facilities in Turkish port cities including Mersin, Ceyhan, and Marmara Ereğlisi before reshipping similar volumes to EU destinations[1][2][3]. Since the EU's petroleum products ban took effect in February 2023 through early 2024, Europe imported €3.1 billion worth of oil products from three Turkish ports with no refining facilities, while 86% of those ports' imports came from Russia during the same period, according to research by the Centre for Research on Energy and Clean Air[2][4][3].

The findings underscore the challenge Europe faces in severing energy ties with Moscow despite ambitious targets. On December 3, EU lawmakers reached a deal to ban all Russian gas imports by autumn 2027, marking what European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen called "the dawn of a new era, the era of Europe's full energy independence from Russia"[5][6][7][8]. The agreement prohibits Russian liquefied natural gas by end of 2026 and pipeline gas by September 2027[5][9].

items.title: Thailand and Cambodia sign ceasefire to end deadly border clashes

featured_image.name: What's in the Thai-Cambodia peace agreement and can it hold?

items.description:
Thailand and Cambodia signed a ceasefire agreement on Saturday to end nearly three weeks of intense border clashes that killed more than 100 people and displaced over half a million residents, marking the second such truce between the neighbors in six months.

The agreement, signed by Thai Defense Minister Natthaphon Narkphanit and Cambodian Defense Minister Tea Seiha at a border checkpoint in Chanthaburi province, takes effect at noon local time on December 27[1][2][3]. The joint statement calls for "an immediate ceasefire...involving all types of weapons, including attacks on civilians, civilian objects and infrastructures"[1][2].

The accord ends 20 days of fighting that has killed at least 101 people and displaced more than 500,000 on both sides[3][4]. According to the Straits Times, the agreement stipulates that "both sides agree to maintain current troop deployments without further movement," with any reinforcement likely to "heighten tensions and negatively affect long-term efforts to resolve the situation"[3].

items.description: The son of a former Bangladesh prime minister has returned to the country after more than 17 years in exile[1].
